zc.thread
Class RendezVous

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--zc.thread.RendezVous
Deprecated. replaced by the SynchronousChannel class. :NOTE: rehabilite this class instead of the SynchronousChannel.

public class RendezVous
extends java.lang.Object

RendezVous, sometime called request-reply, is a message passing protocol used to support client-server interaction. Client processes send request messages to a server process requesting the server to perform some service. These request messages are queued to a FIFO list. The server accepts requests from the FIFO list and upon completion of the requested service sends a reply message to the client that make the request. The client blocks waiting for the reply message. RendezVous involves many-to-one communication in that many clients may request services from a single server. The reply to a request is a one-to-one communication from the server process to the client that requested the service. Case 1: Conditions: Task A requests a rendezvous with Task B Task B is suspended waiting to accept a rendezvous Actions: Task A is suspended, while Task B executes the code for the rendezvous Case 2: Conditions: Task A requests a rendezvous with Task B Task B is not waiting to accept a rendezvous Actions: Task A is suspended, and the request for the rendezvous is placed on a queue Case 3: Conditions: Task B decides to accept rendezvous There are no queued rendezvous Actions: Task B is suspended, awaiting a rendezvous request Case 4: Conditions: Task B decides to accept rendezvous There are queued rendezvous Actions: Task B executes the code for one queued rendezvous request The suspended task associated with the queued rendezvous is unsuspended
